subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] The principles of my dictionary
msgSnippet: ... I think in order to judge this, many of us would have to see it in use. I would like to see specific words spelled with the mergers you describe below. I
messageBody:
Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
>

>
> I don't know if it would be possible to combine mine and
> Paul's dictionary efforts, since the goals of my dictionary
> are rather specific.
>

>
> I think everyone agrees that it is desirable to preserve the
> unity of English spelling after spelling reform, not least
> in view of the role of English as an international contact
> language and the interests of users of English as a second
> language. If Britons, Americans and others start to write
> English each according to their own spelling norm -- with QS
> or any other spelling reform -- they will soon cease to read
> and understand texts written in another country, and
> English, or at any rate the QS community, will effectively
> be split into several distinct languages, simply for the two
> reasons that it will be easier to read texts written
> according to the same spelling norm as one self uses, and
> that people tend to think of different spelling norms as
> different languages.

I think in order to judge this, many of us would have to see it in use.
I would like to see specific words spelled with the mergers you describe
below. I have always somewhat leaned towards a standardized spelling,
but others have spoken out against it, so I guess you have the problem
of convincing the group.


>
> The reason for not distinguishing THOUGHT from LOT is
> mainly that

My dictionary makes the distinction between THOUGHT and LOT. If we
decide on your spelling reform, it is very easy to merge THOUGHT and LOT
later (I think).

>
> - it simplifies the above spelling rule -- you don't need
> to introduce subrules for when /A/ is spelled _au, aw,
> augh, ough_.
> - the CLOTH set straddles the boundary, being pronounced
> with /Q/ and belonging with LOT in some accents and
> pronounced with /O/ and belonging with THOUGHT in other
> accents. Merging the three sets allows everyone to spell
> CLOTH words the same way. (There is of course a third
> group of accents where all three sets have /A/ -- the
> uniform spelling with {Q} will be a simplification for
> them too.)
> - the functional load[^2] of the LOT-THOUGHT distinction
> is low in those accents which make it.

Being an American speaker, I can't hear the CLOTH set at all, but this
seems to make sense.

>
> The TRAP and FATHER sets are also not distinguished, since
> the functional load of that distinction is small, and is
> missing for many speakers in the North of England, Scotland
> and Northern Ireland, not to mention many ESL speakers.

Unfortunately with my dictionary, you can't simply merge these two sets
later. If you do a simple replacement where {A} gets changed to {a}, you
would change words like {TAt} to {Tat}. So I guess here our efforts on
making a dictionary merge.

>
> An exception is made for the START and NORTH-FORCE sets for
> two reasons:
>
> - These sets are pronounced with /A/ and /O/ respectively
> in all major accents of English, and
> - The QS combinations {Qr} and {ar} are awkward to write
> compared to {Or} and {Ar} (although IMO {O} and {A} are
> more difficult to write than {Q} and {a} in many other
> contexts).

For my accent (and I think all others), I think of the /Or/ in FORCE and
the /Ar/ in START as unique combinations; we hear the vowel and the _r_
as one sound, or think of it as such, so I see no problem with this
exception.

>
> If I were to base an inter-English spelling reform on some
> another alphabet than QS I might also merge STRUT-FOOT or
> even all of STRUT-FOOT- GOOSE, but Read's grounds for using
> the letter {y} as he did, for both /V/ and /y/ and with {yr}
> for /3(r)/ were quite solid, and after all most speakers of
> English do distinguish STRUT from FOOT, so I see no pressing
> need deviate from Read's practice in this case.

Actually, I am not so certain that Read's decision was based on solid
grounds. The {y} has to serve for /3/, /V/, and /y/. In my opinion this
leads to confusion, as I have discussed before, when reading words like
_arrest_ and _urge_, spelled respectively {yrEst} and {yrJ}. Both words
start with {yr}, but the first words is pronounced /yr/, while the
second is pronounced /3r/, and those sounds are very different for me,
and make me have to re-read the word to get its sense.

Moreover, I don't know if Read himself thought this a wise decision. He
devised 3 alphabets in his life time, the Shavian script, the
Quikscript, and Readspel. QS came in the middle of those two alphabets.
In Readspell, which came last and Read finished a few days before his
death, Read put both /V/ and /3r/ back into his alphabet. If he thought
his decision to combine /3r/ /V/ and /y/ sound, I don't think he would
have done so.

http://members.aol.com/RSRICHMOND/quickscript.html


>
> [^1]: In the following QS letters and spellings are given
> according to QS-SAMPA and enclosed in curly braces {lYk
> DIs}, TO letters and spellings are given between
> underscores _like this_. English phonemes are given in
> slashes /laIk DIs/ in a SAMPA transcription modified
> towards QS-SAMPA in that /y/ and /a/ are used rather
> than /@/ and /{/. Phonetic transcription where necessary
> is given in a similarly modified SAMPA in square
> brackets [lyIk Dys].
>

I think this method works very well and I hope everyone follows it. One
question about /y/ /a/ vs /@/ /{/. I thought that /y/ and /a/ were
standards for a English-based SAMPA, whereas /{/ and /@/ were the
counterparts for X-SAMPA. Are /a/ and /y/ simply our modification of a
standard?

Paul
